channel.title: New Bot Proposal (no need for updating)
channel.description:
I was talking to Newbiehacker the other day and it gave me an idea for an awesome bot that would not require downloading any copyrighted files or anything, It could actually be ran from the webpage at runescape.com :eek: :D
Have you ever heard of [url=http://jakarta.apache.org/bcel/]BCEL[/url]? Ive been looking into it and it seems it can not only be used to edit bytecode in the file format (like a deobfuscator), but it can be used to edit bytecode AT RUNTIME, while IN memory, according to newbiehacker it can even be used to edit values and even to replace full method bodies while the in the JVM, this would be awesome for a bot.
So what do you guys think? :) :D

item.title: New Bot Proposal (no need for updating)
item.dc:creator: @eXemplar eXemplar
item.description:
@eXemplar wrote:

Basically this is how I planned (I also had a basic implementation going, but because serp sucks it didn't go too well) on doing this,

Load the loader.jar from rs.com with a modified url class loader so you can jerry rig/scan the classes for the methods/fields you need as they're loaded into a frame of an applet so you can post awt events to it. Then, with the vars we know we need, dynamically hack up a stub sort of accessor methods class to get the data through reflection.

It's pretty trivial to load up the applet in a frame and make it think it's coming from rs.com without needing to touch any code inside the client itself, but because matching the vars you want from straight bytecode is a lot harder and more annoying to track down than by source I thought that wouldn't be the best way to go, although it is quite possible and with a framework in place you can delegate sifting through the bytecode to the plebs that hang around.

Read full topic

item.title: New Bot Proposal (no need for updating)
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Pwnd:

You know when you compile a java file into a class file? Well, the bytecode is what is in the .class.
The bytecode is what makes Java universal, because the JRE reads it all the same and JRE is for a bunch of different OSs.

That's how bluntly I could put it. You can't open the .class as you would the .java. You'd just get an assload of symbols and shit. Sometimes you can make the strings out, but even then, you can't read the code.

Read full topic

item.title: New Bot Proposal (no need for updating)
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Arkanor:

I'm sorry, but I've been hearing that term for a while, and rather than persist in silent ignorance, I'd like to display it openly. What is the 'bytecode'? I have a mental image of BCEL using binary, but that can't be right.

You know when you compile a java file into a class file? Well, the bytecode is what is in the .class.
The bytecode is what makes Java universal, because the JRE reads it all the same and JRE is for a bunch of different OSs.

Read full topic

item.title: New Bot Proposal (no need for updating)
item.dc:creator: @newbiehacker newbiehacker
item.description:
@newbiehacker wrote:

well, the basic idea is overwriting the ClassLoader that runescape loads from (look at http://sl8.runescape.com/loader.jar)
edit cloader, make it return true in the verifying method and then make it load the edited class into the memory and voila it would edit the client on-the-fly from the loader before you even start playing the game.

oh yeah and also, when loading from the loader, it sets itself as signlink.mainapp therefor making IT the class that controls getCodeBase() etc.

Read full topic

item.title: New Bot Proposal (no need for updating)
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

/**
 * Date: Mar 12, 2006
 *
 * A demo of BCEL. Not a good setup for more than one edit.
 * @author Krichevskoy
 */
import org.apache.bcel.classfile.*;
import org.apache.bcel.generic.*;
import org.apache.bcel.Repository;
import org.apache.bcel.util.InstructionFinder;
import java.util.Iterator;
public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws java.io.IOException {
 try {
    JavaClass clazz = Repository.lookupClass("client");
    Method[] methods = clazz.getMethods();
    ConstantPoolGen cpg = new ConstantPoolGen(clazz.getConstantPool());

    for(int i = 0; i < methods.length; i++) {
        MethodGen mg = new MethodGen(methods[i], clazz.getClassName(), cpg);
        Method edited = removeFrameTrap(mg);
        if(edited != null)
            methods[i] = edited;
    }

    clazz.setConstantPool(cpg.getFinalConstantPool());
    clazz.dump(clazz.getClassName() + "_edit.class");
 } catch (ClassNotFoundException e) {e.printStackTrace();}
}

public static Method removeFrameTrap(MethodGen mg) {
    InstructionList il = mg.getInstructionList();
    InstructionFinder finder = new InstructionFinder(il);
    String pattern = "IFNULL ALOAD GETFIELD SIPUSH SIPUSH INVOKEVIRTUAL ALOAD GETFIELD LDC INVOKEVIRTUAL";
    Method m = null;
    int count = 0;

    for(Iterator<InstructionHandle[]> i = finder.search(pattern); i.hasNext();) {
        InstructionHandle[] match = i.next();
        try {
            il.delete(match[0].getInstruction(), match[match.length-1].getInstruction());
            count++;
        } catch (TargetLostException tle) { tle.printStackTrace();}
    }

    if(count > 0) {
        System.out.println("Removed frame trap instructions from method " +
		mg.getName());
        m = mg.getMethod();
    }
    il.dispose();
    return m;

}
}

I haven't actually tested this (I know it removes the code, but don't know if the client still works afterward), but it should remove the frame trap from an obfuscated client.

Read full topic

item.title: New Bot Proposal (no need for updating)
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

Ha, finally someone else has discovered bytecode editing! I <3 newbiehacker.

I've done some experimental stuff with these libraries (javassist mostly because it's extremely easier, but BCEL when I need direct editing power) and they work wonderfully. The problem of finding which methods to edit is still there, but I never really mastered BCEL and I believe it has some pretty powerful instruction searching. What bytecode editing does remove is the need for deobfuscation, which I love. Ask pplsuqbawlz about BCEL. In fact, I wish he were around so I could ask him about it but he seems to have disappeared into the ether.

As for decompiling SBoT, you can still interpret the obfuscated code?

Read full topic
